newsitem.title: JORDAN: Jordan market buttressed by institutional demand.
newsitem.headline: Jordan market buttressed by institutional demand.

text.p: Jordan's stock market was steady on Sunday with healthy institutional demand but price corrections blunted further rises, dealers said.

The official Amman Financial Market 60-share index rose a slight 0.03 percent to 151.65 points, buttressed by improved institutional buying which helped raise turnover to a high 1,482,199 dinars ($2.1 million).
There was however one large bloc sale worth 547,773 dinars in Industrial Development Bank, which accounted for over a third of daily volume.
Also, continued selling on large capitalised firms that saw price corrections on Saturday, the new year's first trading session, helped weigh down on the market, dealers and analysts said.
"The market was good with generally healthy institutional demand but price corrections in a number of shares weakened the bourse's rise," said Mohammad Abdulah, an analyst with Pearl Consulting.

Stock closing levels had been artificially bolstered in stepped-up portfolio buying in the last week of 1996, especially on larger capitalised blue-chips, in window dressing transactions to reduce loss provisions.

Price rises in two market heavyweights, Arab Bank and Jordan Cement Factories, helped underpin the official index. The first posted a 2 dinars rise to 251 dinars and the second a 0.02 dinars gain to 3.37 dinars,
The market is currently underpinned by brighter performance of industrials that stand to benefit from exports to Iraq, which helped give the market a good 1997 kick-off on Saturday.

Most of the short-term investor focus is on drug, vegetable oils and detergent firms which have won export orders under Iraq's U.N. approved "oil-for food" deal, which investors say should improve half-year 1997 results.

Investors hopes were raised of business opportunities in the Iraqi market that could breathe new life into the Amman bourse after recent orders exceeding $100 million were secured by leading Jordanian firms under the oil-for-food deal.
The private Pearl Investable Index of the 45 best performing shares on the exchange shed 0.33 percent to 82.61 points from 82.88 points.
Losing shares outnumbered gainers on Sunday by 20 to 12, with shares in nine other firms trading but closing unchanged.
